claim: Archaeologists spend most of their time excavating historical sites.

supporting.text: Excavation is a fundamental method in archaeology for uncovering and analyzing material remains of past human activity.

attacks.text: Excavation is a fundamental method in archaeology for uncovering and analyzing material remains of past human activity.
Excavation is only one part of archaeology; much time is spent on lab analysis, documentation, and research.
Many archaeological projects focus on non-excavation methods like remote sensing or surface surveys.
Even when excavation occurs, it is often a small fraction of the total project timeline due to permitting and planning.

supporting.text: Archaeologists often spend significant time in laboratories analyzing artifacts rather than excavating sites.

attacks.text: Archaeologists often spend significant time in laboratories analyzing artifacts rather than excavating sites.
Excavation is the most visible and resource-intensive part of archaeology, requiring extensive fieldwork.
Many archaeological projects involve minimal lab work, focusing primarily on excavation and site documentation.
Modern archaeology increasingly relies on non-invasive techniques like LiDAR, reducing excavation time.
Non-invasive methods still require follow-up excavations to verify findings, maintaining excavation's centrality.

supporting.text: Fieldwork, including excavation, is a primary activity for many archaeologists as it provides direct access to historical data.

attacks.text: Fieldwork, including excavation, is a primary activity for many archaeologists as it provides direct access to historical data.
Many archaeologists focus on lab analysis, documentation, and theoretical work, which can take up more time than excavation.
Even for field archaeologists, excavation is often seasonal and limited by permits, funding, and weather conditions.
Modern archaeology increasingly relies on non-invasive techniques like LiDAR and ground-penetrating radar, reducing the need for excavation.
Non-invasive methods still require follow-up excavation to verify findings, maintaining excavation as a core activity.

supporting.text: Archaeologists also dedicate substantial time to archival research, which does not involve excavation.

attacks.text: Archaeologists also dedicate substantial time to archival research, which does not involve excavation.
Excavation is still the primary activity for many archaeologists, especially those in field archaeology.
Field archaeology is only one specialization; many archaeologists focus on lab analysis or theoretical work, which involves little to no excavation.
Even when not excavating, archaeologists often analyze excavated artifacts, so their work remains closely tied to excavation.
Artifact analysis is a distinct phase that follows excavation and does not itself involve digging, so it does not support the claim about spending 'most time' excavating.

supporting.text: Excavation requires extensive planning and permits, which can limit the time spent on actual digging.

attacks.text: Excavation requires extensive planning and permits, which can limit the time spent on actual digging.
Many archaeological projects involve long-term excavations where most fieldwork is dedicated to digging once permits are secured.
Even with permits, bureaucratic delays and logistical challenges can still reduce active excavation time significantly.
Excavation is only one part of archaeology; researchers spend substantial time on lab analysis, documentation, and publication.
Fieldwork, including excavation, remains the most time-intensive phase in many archaeological projects despite other responsibilities.

supporting.text: Many archaeological projects involve long-term site preservation, which reduces the emphasis on excavation.

attacks.text: Many archaeological projects involve long-term site preservation, which reduces the emphasis on excavation.
Excavation is still a core activity in archaeology, even if preservation is prioritized in some projects.
Excavation is often necessary before preservation efforts can begin, making it an unavoidable part of the process.
Many archaeological grants and research projects explicitly require excavation as a primary deliverable.
Public perception and media representation of archaeology often focus on excavation, which may skew professional priorities.
